channel.title: NYT > Business
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: Saudi Arabia, Once Shunned, Has Corporate Titans Swooning for Deals
item.description: Some of the most prominent U.S. executives gathered at the Kennedy Center for an event promoting deal-making with the oil-rich kingdom.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:description: President Trump posing next to Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia for a group photo at the U.S.-Saudi Investment Forum at the Kennedy Center in Washington.

item.title: Nvidia Earnings Fuel Rally in Global Technology Stocks
item.description: The chipmaker’s profit surge and strong revenue forecast helped to ease fears that spending on A.I. infrastructure might be outpacing demand.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis and Joe Rennison
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: A trader on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange on Wednesday. In the United States, Nvidia shares climbed more than 5 percent in after-hours trading.

item.title: Saudi Arabia’s Prince Has Big Plans, but His Giant Fund Is Low on Cash
item.description: After nearly a decade of expensive, hit-and-miss investments, Mohammed bin Salman is overseeing a behind-the-scenes restructuring of the kingdom’s all-important wealth fund.
item.dc:creator: Rob Copeland and Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: President Trump welcomed Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia to the White House on Tuesday.

item.title: Mexico Is Now the United States’ Top Buyer
item.description: For first time in at least 30 years, the United States has exported more to Mexico than Canada, U.S. government data show, in a sign of how much North American trade has consolidated.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Gabriel V. Cárdenas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Trucks moving goods from the United States to Mexico in February. “Mexico is the United States’ main trading partner,” said Marcelo Ebrard, Mexico’s economy minister.

item.title: After Shutdown, Labor Department Says Some Data is Gone for Good
item.description: Surveys were delayed and some cannot be collected at all, officials said, further complicating the Federal Reserve’s decision on interest rates next month.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis and Colby Smith
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Incomplete data has major implications for central bank officials debating whether to lower interest rates for a third meeting in a row.

item.title: December Rate Cut in Doubt as Fed Fault Lines Deepen, Minutes Show
item.description: The central bank’s decision to lower interest rates last month was more divisive than it first appeared as officials splintered over how to weigh a weakening labor market against rising inflation.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, said recently that officials at the central bank held “strongly differing views.”

item.title: Iran Releases Tanker It Seized From the Strait of Hormuz
item.description: The ship had lost contact with its managers while traveling near Iran on its way to Singapore last week. All 21 members of the crew are safe.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar
item.media:description: A quarter of the world’s oil passes through the Strait of Hormuz, where Iran seized a tanker on Friday.

item.title: Saudi Arabia Backs Elon Musk’s xAI With Data Center Deal
item.description: Mr. Musk’s xAI will work with the Saudi artificial intelligence company Humain on a new data center, part of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman’s effort to diversify his kingdom’s economy.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano and Paul Mozur
item.media:description: Elon Musk and Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia in Washington on Wednesday. The deal between xAI and the Saudi-backed company Humain is set to be xAI’s biggest data center outside the United States.

item.title: Trump’s Tariffs Sent Trade Plummeting in August
item.description: The steep tariffs President Trump issued in August led to a contraction in imports and the trade deficit, newly released data shows.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: The C.E.O.s Who Came to Dinner (With the Saudi Crown Prince)
item.description: The presence of business leaders at a White House event for Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman underscores a deepening of U.S. and Saudi ties.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe and Ian Mount
item.media:description: Dozens of top business leaders flocked to the White House for a dinner President Trump hosted for Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia.

item.title: Netherlands Hands Back Control of Chinese-Owned Chipmaker Nexperia
item.description: Uncertainty over the availability of the company’s chips, which are used in cars and electronics, had added to concerns of a global shortage.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: The headquarters of Nexperia, a Dutch chipmaker owned by the Chinese company Wingtech.

item.title: Nvidia and Walmart Could Ease Wall St.’s Jitters. Or Make Them Worse.
item.description: After four consecutive down days, the stock market is looking increasingly queasy. Earnings reports from Nvidia, Walmart and Target could hint at what’s ahead.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison

item.title: For Victims of Sexual Assault on Cruise Ships, Justice Can Be Elusive
item.description: As cruise travel hits record demand, cases of sexual assault have also risen. Many accusers learn that the rights they had on land don’t always apply.
item.dc:creator: Ceylan Yeğinsu
item.category: National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism
Rape, Abuse and Incest National Network (RAINN)
item.media:description: Though the 2010 Cruise Vessel Security and Safety Act established training standards, only one crew member on each vessel must be trained in crime prevention and evidence gathering.

item.title: Europe’s Chip Dreams Confront Business Realities
item.description: European chipmakers need TSMC’s help to grow their own semiconductor supply chain, but the chip giant’s Taiwanese suppliers find Europe a tough place to do business.
item.dc:creator: Meaghan Tobin and Xinyun Wu
item.media:credit: Milan Bures for The New York Times
item.media:description: TSMC is teaming up with European chipmakers to build a factory near Dresden, Germany, as Europe’s need to make its own chips has grown more pressing.

item.title: At $236 Million, Klimt Piece Is Second Most Expensive Painting Sold at Auction
item.description: At $236.4 million, a portrait by Gustav Klimt is the second most expensive painting sold at auction, while Maurizio Cattelan’s golden toilet drew $12.1 million.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small and Julia Halperin
item.media:description: Modern art history: The auctioneer at Sotheby’s, Oliver Barker, hammered down a final bid on a portrait of Elisabeth Lederer by Klimt.

item.title: Here’s Who’s Attending Trump’s Dinner for the Saudi Crown Prince: Elon Musk, Cristiano Ronaldo and more.
item.description: Here are some of the notable guests invited to President Trump’s dinner for Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump at a dinner on Tuesday during the Saudi crown prince’s visit to Washington.

item.title: Trump Berates Mary Bruce of ABC News After Question About Jamal Khashoggi
item.description: The president grew frustrated with Mary Bruce of ABC News over her questions during his meeting with the Saudi crown prince. On Friday, he told a Bloomberg News reporter, “Quiet, piggy.”
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum
item.media:description: Mary Bruce, the chief White House correspondent for ABC News, in the Oval Office on Tuesday.

item.title: Home Depot Cuts Forecast as Consumers Pull Back on Spending
item.description: The big box retailer said tariff costs and elevated mortgage rates had slowed consumer spending on new homes and remodeling projects.
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Rhone
item.media:description: Home Depot missed its earnings targets last quarter, citing economic uncertainty and elevated mortgage rates as reasons consumers had pulled back on spending.

item.title: U.S. Fraud Case Against Indian Tycoon Adani at a Standstill
item.description: The case against Gautam Adani, the infrastructure titan and a close associate of Prime Minister Narendra Modi, has stalled with no sign of progress.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli and Santul Nerkar
item.media:description: Gautam Adani in January. He was indicted two weeks after President Trump won re-election, but the case has remained dormant.

item.title: Trump Family’s Business Ties to Saudi Arabia Raise Ethics Worries
item.description: President Trump will host Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, Saudi Arabia’s de facto ruler, who oversees a major construction project that is in talks with the Trump family business.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: President Trump, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman and Jerry Inzerillo at a model of the proposed Diriyah development during a state dinner in Saudi Arabia in May.

item.title: The Growing Cost of Keeping Close Ties with Jeffrey Epstein
item.description: Larry Summers, a former Treasury secretary, is stepping back from public commitments. It’s the latest fallout for an associate of Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly and Brian O’Keefe
item.media:credit: David Degner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Larry Summers, a former Treasury secretary, has decided to step back from public life in the wake of the Jeffrey Epstein scandal.

item.title: Cloudflare Outage Disrupts X, ChatGPT and Other Parts of the Internet
item.description: Services from Cloudflare, a software company, underpin thousands of websites, including X, Spotify and OpenAI. The company said a crash in a software system was to blame.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:description: Cloudflare’s headquarters in San Francisco.

item.title: Paramount, Comcast and Netflix Prepare Bids for Warner Bros. Discovery
item.description: Paramount, Comcast and Netflix are preparing bids to buy all or part of Warner Bros. Discovery, a crown jewel of the industry.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin, Lauren Hirsch and Nicole Sperling
item.media:description: Thursday is the deadline for initial bids for Warner Bros. Discovery, which owns the Warner Bros. studio, above.

item.title: A City Is Broke. Can Billionaires’ Urbanist Dream Offer It a Last Chance?
item.description: Suisun City has tried to revive its fortunes for years. The latest idea: Annex land owned by California Forever, a tech-billionaire-funded plan for a new city north of San Francisco.
item.dc:creator: Conor Dougherty
item.media:credit: Aaron Wojack for The New York Times
item.media:description: Suisun City, Calif., has ping-ponged between the threat of insolvency and revitalization plans that tend to fizzle out.

item.title: We Now Have a Better Picture of China’s Global Lending Spree
item.description: Beijing has used loans to developing nations to expand its influence, but a new study says no country has received more Chinese financing than the United States.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:credit: Nathan Howard for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Amazon Web Services data center in Ashburn, Va. Some of China’s financing in the United States has been in the form of lines of credit to big companies like Amazon.

item.title: Energy Companies Turn to Fossil Fuels, 10 Years After Climate Pact
item.description: Recent oil and gas deals in Europe suggest that the growing demand for energy may be leading companies to adopt a more pragmatic approach.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.media:credit: Desiré van den Berg for The New York Times
item.media:description: TotalEnergies uses facilities like gas-fired power plants and this battery farm on the site of a closed refinery near Dunkirk, France, to balance the power grid.

item.title: Trump Says America Is in ‘Golden Age,’ Straining to Address Affordability
item.description: Speaking at a gathering of McDonald’s franchise owners and operators, the president boasted that he had “normalized” inflation.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green
item.media:credit: Allison Robbert for The New York Times
item.media:description: In his remarks at the McDonald’s Impact Summit on Monday in Washington, President Trump made only fleeting reference to the issue of beef prices, after boasting about getting his health secretary, Robert F. Kennedy Jr., to eat a Big Mac.

item.title: Larry Summers to Step Back From Public Commitments Over Epstein Emails
item.description: New emails showed that Mr. Summers, a former Harvard president, had stayed in touch with Jeffrey Epstein for years after Mr. Epstein faced sex trafficking charges.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel
item.media:credit: David Degner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. Summers, a former treasury secretary, had sought money from Mr. Epstein for a poetry foundation led by his wife, Elisa New, an emerita Harvard literature professor.

item.title: The Fed Is Cutting Bank Oversight. Critics See Risks.
item.description: The regulator is cutting staff and easing oversight in ways that critics say might make supervisors less equipped to spot a crisis in advance, risking deeper damage to the economy.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith and Stacy Cowley
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Michelle W. Bowman has vowed to overhaul the division she was tapped by President Trump to lead.

item.title: High Beef Prices? Trump Official Blames Biden and Migrants.
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said migrants were bringing sick cows across the border, snarling beef supply chains.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: For President Trump, who served fast food sandwiches to the Clemson University football team during its 2019 visit to the White House, few meals hit closer to home than hamburgers.

item.title: Trump Project in Maldives Opens More Doors for Cryptocurrency Investors
item.description: The Trump Organization and its Middle East development partner have announced a project in the Maldives that marries two of the family’s most successful moneymaking enterprises.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca R. Ruiz and Eric Lipton
item.category: Dar Al Arkan Real Estate Development Co
item.media:description: Eric Trump, the executive vice president of the Trump Organization and the president’s son, looked over a real estate plan on another project involving the Dubai-based company Dar Global in Doha in April.

item.title: As Struggling Farmers Take On Debt, a Bailout From D.C. May Come Too Late
item.description: It could be months before they receive aid, well after the winter period when they talk to their bankers and make decisions about the planting ahead.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Draper
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Agriculture Department spokesman said he had no new details on plans for federal farm aid.

item.title: Europe Begins Rethinking Its Crackdown on Big Tech
item.description: European policymakers are crafting changes to scale back and simplify landmark rules for A.I. and data privacy, in a shift from an aggressive regulatory period.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano and Jeanna Smialek

item.title: Jeff Bezos’ Big Bet on A.I. Is Project Prometheus
item.description: The Amazon founder is tapping his fortune to help fund Project Prometheus, an artificial intelligence start-up, even as he has said A.I. may be in a bubble.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe and Ian Mount
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jeff Bezos is returning to the C-suite — for an A.I. start-up.

item.title: These Six Artworks Could Predict the Auction Market
item.description: The art market had a summer of closures and consolidations. But major collections, blue-chip art and guarantees have pushed expectations high for the marquee sales.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small, Julia Halperin and Tim F. Schneider
item.media:credit: OK McCausland for The New York Times
item.media:description: A viewer crouches next to Maurizio Cattelan’s artwork-as-loo.

item.title: Hydropower Is Getting Less Reliable as the World Needs More Energy
item.description: Demand for power is growing fast, but hydro plants, the oldest source of clean energy, are struggling because of droughts, floods and other extreme weather linked to climate change.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Ruth Fremson

item.title: How to Not Get Kidnapped for Your Bitcoin
item.description: Escaping zipties, hiring bodyguards and other practical lessons in self-defense for crypto traders, after a series of gruesome crimes spooked the community.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany and Maurizio Fiorino
item.media:credit: Maurizio Fiorino for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kevin Harris, a security consultant, pushing a metal tool into a ziptie during a training workshop in Switzerland.

item.title: The Crypto Industry’s $28 Billion in ‘Dirty Money’
item.description: As President Trump has championed crypto and the industry has gone mainstream, funds from scammers and other criminal groups have flowed onto major crypto exchanges.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany, Spencer Woodman and Sam Ellefson

item.title: Trump Tariffs Push Japan’s Economy Into Contraction
item.description: The Japanese economy shrank 1.8 percent from the same quarter last year as U.S. tariffs dampened automobile exports and prompted a bleak outlook for growth.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis
item.media:description: The economic contraction in Japan is the latest indicator of how President Trump’s trade policies are disrupting the global economy and placing pressure on the United States’ top trade partners worldwide.

item.title: Matthew Belloni Is Yelling ‘Iceberg!’ on the Hollywood Titanic
item.description: Matthew Belloni has grabbed the movie industry’s attention by saying they’re about to sink.
item.dc:creator: Irina Aleksander
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Matthew Belloni, right, has become a must-read in Hollywood. “You could argue his voice and sensibility are what the public wants right now,” said one executive producer.

item.title: Pasta at Twice the Price? Some Italian Producers Face Huge U.S. Tariffs.
item.description: More than a dozen Italian pasta makers, accused of dumping their product in the United States, face tariffs of over 100 percent.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson and Gianni Cipriano
item.media:description: Mezze penne rigate pass along a rolling conveyor after the drying phase.

item.title: They Got Low Mortgage Rates During the Pandemic. Now They Can’t Move.
item.description: Many Americans bought their first houses when mortgage rates dipped to record lows. Some are ready to move but feel locked in by their low rates.
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Rhone
item.media:credit: Janice Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sandy Lachhman and Shaun Parmassar in front of their home, purchased in 2022 right before interest rates went up.

item.title: Former Fed Official Violated Trading Rules, Disclosures Show
item.description: Adriana D. Kugler, who stepped down as a governor in August, reported trades in stocks, including Apple and Southwest Airlines, in 2024.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith
item.media:description: Adriana Kugler at the Federal Reserve board meeting in June.

item.title: An Economist Asked, How Much Should We Spend to Avoid the A.I. Apocalypse?
item.description: The question “at first struck me as too open-ended to be usefully addressed by standard economics,” said Charles Jones of Stanford. He took a shot anyway.
item.dc:creator: Peter Coy

item.title: What’s the Most Elegant Way to Lie to My Co-Workers?
item.description: Plus, how to say, “No, Chef.”
item.dc:creator: Max Read
item.media:credit: Photo illustration by Margeaux Walter for The New York Times

item.title: Is Your College Football Team Short of Cash? Sports Betting Can Help.
item.description: Louisiana lawmakers tried a novel strategy for raising revenue, a model that proponents say might work more broadly.
item.dc:creator: Jason Schwartz

item.title: Hochul Urged to Ban Horseshoe Crab Fishing
item.description: Supporters of the legislation argue it would protect a declining horseshoe crab population, while opponents warn it will harm the commercial fishing industry.
item.dc:creator: Jon Hurdle
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times
item.media:description: If Gov. Kathy Hochul signs the bill, New York would join New Jersey and Connecticut in stopping the fishing industry from using the crabs as bait for catching other marine species, including the endangered American eel.

item.title: Lil Luv Dog Launches Goop-Like Beauty Brand for Dogs
item.description: A line of upscale pet products from Lil Luv Dog is marketed like a beauty and lifestyle brand, is human-grade in quality, and is priced to match.
item.dc:creator: Cheryl Wischhover
item.media:credit: Gabriella Angotti-Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stephanie Suganami and Cara Santana Leto created Lil Luv Dog, a beauty brand for dogs, based on their experiences with their own dogs: Sheppy, Binx and Mercer.

item.title: Disney and YouTube TV End Blackout
item.description: After a 15-day standoff, a deal cleared the way for YouTube TV to resume carrying ESPN, ABC and other Disney-owned channels.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes
item.media:description: YouTube TV and Disney reached an agreement before a busy Saturday of college football on ABC and ESPN.

item.title: Trump Administration Lifts Some Food Tariffs in Effort to Ease Prices
item.description: It is walking back levies on imports including beef and coffee in what critics say is an admission that tariffs raised prices in the first place.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: Though President Trump campaigned on lowering the price of groceries, concerns about affordability helped propel Democrats to win elections across the country last week.
